metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Respondents

facts.text: Towards latter part of 1950, systematic misappropriation of Government monies in certain Calcutta post offices including one where first respondent was Sub Postmaster, by affixing used postage stamps.

Police appoint foot constable as Packer in Sub Post Office to watch; on information, raid conducted in September 1950; first respondent (Sub Postmaster), respondent 2 (Money Order clerk), respondent 3 (Registration clerk) arrested.
Charges include offences under s.409 and s.120B/409 of Indian Penal Code.

Police complete investigation; charge-sheet submitted on 16-1-1951 to Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, charging offences under s.120B r/w s.409 IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act; case registered as Crime Case No. 136 of 1951; Magistrate takes cognizance.
Government of West Bengal issues notification on 1-2-1951 under s.4(1) West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949, allotting case to Special Judge at Alipore.
Chief Presidency Magistrate on 16-2-1951 orders records sent to Special Judge Alipore, accused to appear on 5-3-1951.

First respondent files petition under Art.226 Constitution before Calcutta High Court impugning constitutional validity of s.4(1) of the Act as violative of Art.14; Full Bench allows petition on 4-4-1952, strikes down s.4(1), holds Special Judge has no jurisdiction, directs accused held as under-trial pending retrial according to law.
Ordinance 8 of 1952 promulgated on 9-4-1952 amending the Act.
Charge-sheets against respondents re-filed before Special Judge Alipore; summons issued on 2-6-1952.
First respondent prefers revision to High Court to quash proceedings before Special Judge and summons.

Ordinance lapses; replaced by West Bengal Act 12 of 1952, containing s.12: 'Nothing in this Act shall apply to any proceedings pending on the date of the commencement of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Amending Ordinance, 1952, in any court other than a Special Court.' No saving clause for actions under Ordinance.
High Court on 24-3-1953 disposes revision: holds proceedings under Ordinance terminated on its expiry, summons and proceedings before Special Judge quashed; does not pronounce on s.12.
Government allots case again to Special Court; fresh charge-sheet submitted on 18-6-1953.
First respondent questions Special Judge's jurisdiction invoking s.12; revision to High Court withdrawn and dismissed on 24-5-1954.
Special Judge overrules jurisdiction objection, dismisses petition.

Respondents challenge via Criminal Revision to High Court; dismissed on 12-1-1956: holds s.12 not bar as proceedings initiated after 9-4-1952 (allotment Dec 1952, charge-sheet 18-6-1953); no proceedings pending before Special Judge on 9-4-1952.
First respondent's special leave petition to Supreme Court dismissed without prejudice to raising point later.
Respondents object to Special Judge's jurisdiction based on s.12; Special Judge upholds objection on 22-2-1956, discharges respondents.
State does not challenge Special Judge's order in revision; charge-sheet presented to Chief Presidency Magistrate.
Chief Presidency Magistrate directs issue of process; first respondent files revision objecting to jurisdiction.
High Court on 19-12-1956 allows revision: sets aside Magistrate's order issuing process; holds per 24-3-1953 decision, Special Judge has jurisdiction.
Government allots case again to Special Judge under s.4; fresh charge-sheet filed.
Respondents object to jurisdiction; overruled; sixth Criminal Revision to High Court (No.1128/1957).
High Court on 9-5-1958 allows revision: quashes Special Judge's orders; holds proceedings pending before Chief Presidency Magistrate on 9-4-1952 due to 4-4-1952 order quashing allotment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Special Judge or the Chief Presidency Magistrate has jurisdiction to try the case, particularly effect of s.12 of West Bengal Act 12 of 1952 on proceedings pending on 9-4-1952.
Legal effect of High Court order dated 4-4-1952 quashing allotment to Special Judge: does it revive jurisdiction of Chief Presidency Magistrate?
Whether fresh allotments and charge-sheets after 9-4-1952 constitute new proceedings not hit by s.12.
Binding nature of earlier High Court decisions on jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Legal effect of High Court order dated 4-4-1952 was not to revive proceedings before Chief Presidency Magistrate so as to be pending on 9-4-1952.
High Court order dated 4-4-1952 quashing s.4(1) as unconstitutional was wrong, disapproved in Kedar Nath Bajoria v. State of West Bengal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kedar Nath Bajoria v. State of West Bengal (1954) SCR 30

petitioner_arguments.text: No identity between original proceedings before Magistrate and those before Special Judge quashed, so s.12 wrongly applied.
Earlier High Court decisions dated 12-1-1956 and 19-12-1956 correct and binding.
Even if proceedings pending before Magistrate on 9-4-1952, State can initiate fresh proceedings and allot to Special Judge under s.4(2).

respondent_arguments.text: s.4(1) of Act violative of Art.14; Special Judge has no jurisdiction.
Proceedings before Special Judge under Ordinance terminated on lapse; s.12 bars jurisdiction as case pending before Magistrate on 9-4-1952.
Effect of 4-4-1952 order: proceedings revived/pending before Chief Presidency Magistrate.

court_reasoning.text: Wrong decision by court having jurisdiction is binding; 4-4-1952 order final despite erroneous on constitutionality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Incorrect decision as binding as correct one.

court_reasoning.text: Effect of 4-4-1952 order: allotment void ab initio, restores position before allotment; Chief Presidency Magistrate's jurisdiction revived as he had taken cognizance; proceedings pending before him on 9-4-1952 attracting s.12.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate's order sending records merely ministerial, no effect on jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Subsequent events: 24-3-1953 quashes May 1952 allotment; 12-1-1956 upholds Dec 1952 allotment but SL dismissal without prejudice; 22-2-1956 Special Judge upholds s.12 objection, discharges, accepted by State; 19-12-1956 HC holds Special Judge jurisdiction per prior decisions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 19-12-1956 binding adjudication that Special Court has jurisdiction, s.12 not bar.

court_reasoning.text: Despite 4-4-1952 effect, subsequent binding HC decisions (esp. 19-12-1956) hold Special Court has jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents cannot re-agitate free of binding decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Fresh proceedings argument fails: same offences, facts, accused; s.12 bars allotment of pending cases; fresh allotment evasion of s.12.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.12 protects pending ordinary court proceedings from allotment.

holdings.text: Special Court has jurisdiction due to binding High Court decisions notwithstanding prima facie effect of s.12.
s.12 bars allotment to Special Court of cases pending in ordinary courts on 9-4-1952; fresh allotments for same offences not new proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kedar Nath Bajoria v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Disapproves High Court's 4-4-1952 holding on unconstitutionality of s.4(1), but wrong decision still binding.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Allotment of cases to Special Courts; struck down then amended.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Act 12 of 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Pending proceedings in other courts not affected by Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for challenging s.4(1) as discriminatory.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Calcutta High Court dated 9-5-1958 set aside; Special Court deemed to have jurisdiction over the case.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of proceedings before Special Judge.

key_quotes.text: "The result would therefore be as if there had never been any allotment of the case to the Special judge and therefore there had been no assumption of jurisdiction by him, the allotment being non est."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We consider that to hold that there could be an allotment of a case in respect of an offence for which a complaint before a Magistrate is pending on 9-4-1952, would be a plain evasion of the bar contained in s.12."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A wrong decision by a court having jurisdiction is as much binding between the parties as a right one."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Binding nature of erroneous jurisdictional decisions.
